importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the lawsuit filing and the key event in the political dispute over the swearing-in of Adelita Grijalva.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from late September to October 21, 2025, when Grijalva won the election and the House refused to seat her, culminating in the lawsuit.

keyTakeAways: Arizona’s attorney general has sued the U.S. House of Representatives over Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal to swear in newly elected Democrat Adelita Grijalva due to a government shutdown.
The lawsuit argues that the Constitution requires elected members to be sworn in, regardless of Speaker’s discretion, and that the Speaker lacks constitutional authority to delay seating.
Johnson claims to be following the precedent set by Nancy Pelosi, who delayed swearing-in members after recess, but this is contested by the Arizona legal team.
Grijalva has not spoken to Johnson since winning her election, and she is attempting to schedule a meeting to resolve the standoff.
The lawsuit alleges that Johnson’s delay is politically motivated to block a petition on Jeffrey Epstein records and to strengthen his position in budget negotiations.
The Constitution does not specify who administers the oath, only that representatives must take it; thus, a qualified third party could administer it if needed.
The case raises constitutional questions about the authority of the Speaker to block seating of duly elected members.

namedEntities.name: Adelita Grijalva
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly elected U.S. Representative from Arizona, who won her seat in late September 2025 and whose swearing-in has been blocked by Speaker Mike Johnson.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the central figure in the constitutional and political dispute over whether elected representatives must be seated regardless of Speaker’s discretion.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Republican Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, who has refused to administer the oath of office to Grijalva, citing precedent from Nancy Pelosi.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Johnson’s refusal to seat Grijalva is the core action that sparked the lawsuit and the broader constitutional debate about Speaker authority.

namedEntities.name: Nancy Pelosi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former U.S. Speaker of the House, whose precedent Johnson cites in justifying his delay in swearing in Grijalva.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her past actions in delaying swearing-in members after recess are referenced as a justification for Johnson’s current position, though contested in this case.

namedEntities.name: Arizona Attorney General Kris Mayes
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The head of Arizona’s legal office who filed the lawsuit against the House over Grijalva’s delayed seating.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She represents the state’s legal interest and argues that the Constitution mandates the swearing-in of elected members, regardless of Speaker’s decision.

namedEntities.name: Jeffrey Epstein
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A convicted sex offender whose records are the subject of a petition to be released by Congress.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The lawsuit alleges that Johnson’s delay is an effort to block a petition on Epstein records, suggesting political motivation.

namedEntities.name: U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The legislative body where the dispute over Grijalva’s seating is taking place.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The central institution involved in the constitutional and procedural issue of swearing in newly elected members.

namedEntities.name: Constitution of the United States
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The foundational legal document cited in the lawsuit to support the claim that elected members must be sworn in.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The legal argument hinges on constitutional provisions that require sworn-in members, not Speaker discretion.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Arizona’s attorney general, Kris Mayes, has sued the U.S. House of Representatives over Republican Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal to swear in newly elected Democrat Adelita Grijalva, who won her seat in late September 2025. The lawsuit argues that the Constitution mandates that duly elected members be seated, and that the Speaker lacks constitutional authority to delay swearing-in, especially when no valid reason for delay exists. Johnson claims to be following the precedent of former Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who delayed seating members after recess, but the Arizona legal team counters that this precedent does not justify blocking a new member’s entry. The lawsuit asserts that Johnson’s refusal is politically motivated—aimed at blocking a petition on Jeffrey Epstein records and strengthening his position in budget negotiations. Grijalva, who has not spoken to Johnson since her election, is attempting to meet with him to resolve the dispute. The case raises constitutional concerns about the Speaker’s power and the rights of elected officials to serve immediately in Congress.
title: Arizona Sues Over Mike Johnson’s Refusal to Swear in Democrats’ Newest Congresswoman
